C++ - L-value vs. R-value

Created:2018-01-29  Last modified:2018-01-29

  • Introduction
  • References

  1. Introduction

    Concepts

    1. lvalue: locator value, the value is stored in a memory location, it takes a memory space.

      rvalue: defined by exclusion of lvalue, e.g. immediate value

    2. In an assignment operation, the left side must be an lvalue.
    3. The lvalue can be an reference or a variable.
    4. Not all lvalue can be assigned, const int a = 1;
    5. lvalue can be used as a rvalue, but rvalue cannot be used as a lvalue
    6. * deference can convert a rvalue into a lvalue 
                      int p = 0x11111; 
                *(p + 1) = 10;

    Code illustration

    // return a reference
int global = 10;
int& foo(){ // return the reference of the global variable.
  return global; // local variable cannot be returned, because C++ does not support closure.
}
int main(){
  foo() = 1; // reference is an lvalue, so it can be assigned a value.
  std::cout << foo() << std::endl; // 1
  return 0;
}

    1. Understanding lvalues and rvalues in C and C++
